p.content: Nominal phrases can be very complex. This section concentrates on those with common nouns as the lexical head. Modification by articles, demonstratives, possessors, quantifiers and degree words, adjective phrases, pre/post-positional phrases and noun compounds is considered. Participles and gerunds are also covered, but nominal phrases headed by proper names are handled in section
and those headed by pronouns, demonstratives, and quantifiers are handled in section
. Relative clauses are covered in section
The basic order of elements allowed in nominal phrases in
is:
Each of these phrases will be discussed and exemplified in sections
, after first dealing with agreement and case marking.

Many languages require agreement between at least some of the modifiers and the head noun. While English only has number agreement, in other languages this agreement may also include animacy, class, or gender.
In

case.caseText: there is no number agreement. Instead, number marking comes from the number or quantifier.
the various nominal modifiers may/must agree in number with the head noun.

p.content: Further,

case.caseText: there is no agreement in animacy, class number, nor gender between the modifiers and the head noun.
the modifiers and the head noun may/must agree in animacy.
the modifiers and the head noun may/must agree in class number.
the modifiers and the head noun may/must agree in gender.

text.content: (Note that this class agreement needs to be reviewed, as no classifier system was documented in

p.content: Examples showing number agreement in
nominal phrases include:
Examples showing animacy agreement in
nominal phrases include:
Examples showing class agreement in
nominal phrases include:
Examples showing gender agreement in
nominal phrases include:

Nouns and their modifiers may be marked for case. The most common case system is nominative-accusative. This is the system English has, though only pronouns are marked for case in English. In a nominative-accusative system, subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs are in nominative case, while direct objects are accusative case. Possessors are genitive case. The nominative pronouns in English are:
p.langData: I, we, you, he, she, they
p.content: . The accusative pronouns are:
p.langData: me, us, you, him, her, them
p.content: . The genitive pronouns include:
p.langData: my, our, your, his, her, their
p.content: . Therefore, we say
and not
A language with a basic nominative-accusative case system may have different case marking for Experiencer subjects than for Agent subjects. Some verbs with Experiencer subjects are
p.langData: appear, see, fear, be found, want, like
p.content: and

In an ergative-absolutive case system, subjects of transitive verbs are marked with the ergative case, while objects of transitive verbs and subjects of intransitive verbs are marked with the absolutive case. The case of possessors is not set cross-linguistically. Some languages with an ergative-absolutive system simply have different sets of verbal agreement markers, but no marking on nouns. This type of agreement marking will be handled in section

Some languages are even more complex in that they normally have a nominative-accusative system but under some grammatical conditions, such as a particular tense or aspect or a particular person agreement feature, the case system switches to ergative-absolutive. This is called “split ergativity”.

case.caseText: does not have any case system. The exact same set of pronouns may be used in any position in the sentence and there is no marking on nouns or on any noun modifiers based on their position in the sentence.

has a nominative-accusative case system. Subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs are marked in the same way and use the same set of pronouns, but objects of transitive verbs are marked differently.

has an ergative-absolutive case system. Subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs are marked in the same way and use the same set of pronouns, but subjects of transitive verbs are marked differently.
has a split case system. The language normally follows the nominative-accusative case system, but the ergative-absolutive system is used under certain grammatical conditions.

p.content: This is shown in the following examples of transitive sentences with Agent subjects where the subject and object are nominal phrases:
Note the forms of the pronouns used for the Agent subject and object in these transitive sentences:
In the intransitive examples with nominal phrases as the subjects,

case.caseText: the case marking matches that of the subejcts in the transitive sentences above.
the case marking matches that of the objects in the transitive sentences above.
the case marking on most of the subjects matches that of the subjects in the transitive sentences above, but in certain situations, it matches that of the objects in trantitive sentences.

p.content: The examples of intransitive sentences with independent pronouns as subjects verify that

case.caseText: there is no case distinction, as the same pronouns can appear as subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs and as objects of transitive verbs.
the same set of pronouns can appear as subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs, while different pronouns are used as objects of transitive verbs.
the same set of pronouns can appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs, while different pronouns are used as subjects of transitive verbs.

the same set of pronouns can normally appear as subjects of both transitive and intransitive verbs, while different pronouns are used as objects of transitive verbs. However, in certain cases, the same set of pronouns can appear as subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs, while different pronouns are used as subjects of transitive verbs.

p.content: In

case.caseText: the same case marking and pronoun set is used for both Agent and Experiencer subjects.

Experiencer subjects use the same case marking and pronoun set as objects of transitive verbs with an Agent subject do. We assume that Experiencer subjects have dative case, like indirect objects, so accusative case and dative case are marked the same in this language.
Experiencer subjects use a case marking and pronoun set which is distinct from both the subject and object of verbs with an Agent subject. This is the dative case, also used for indirect objects.

p.content: In

case.caseText: the same pronoun set is used for both Agent and Experiencer subjects.

Experiencer subjects use the same pronoun set as objects of transitive verbs with an Agent subject do. We assume that Experiencer subjects have dative case, like indirect objects, so the accusative and dative pronouns are the same in this language.
Experiencer subjects use a pronoun set which is distinct from both the subject and object of verbs with an Agent subject. These are the dative pronouns, also used for indirect objects.

p.content: In

case.caseText: the same case marking and pronoun set is used for both Agent and Experiencer subjects.

Experiencer subjects use the same case marking and pronoun set as objects of transitive verbs with an Agent subject do. We assume that Experiencer subjects have dative case, like indirect objects, so absolutive case and dative case are marked the same in this language.
Experiencer subjects use a case marking and pronoun set which is distinct from both the subject and object of verbs with an Agent subject. This is the dative case, also used for indirect objects.

p.content: In

case.caseText: the same pronoun set is used for both Agent and Experiencer subjects.

Experiencer subjects use the same pronoun set as objects of transitive verbs with an Agent subject do. We assume that Experiencer subjects have dative case, like indirect objects, so the absolutive and dative pronouns are the same in this language.
Experiencer subjects use a pronoun set which is distinct from both the subject and object of verbs with an Agent subject. These are the dative pronouns, also used for indirect objects.

p.content: This is shown in the following examples of transitive sentences with verbs which have Experiencer subjects, where the subject and object are nominal phrases:
Note the forms of the pronouns used for the Experiencer subjects and the objects in these transitive sentences:

There are more cases to consider beyond that of the subject and object, also. These may include ablative case for a source or origin, genitive case for kinds or possessors, dative case for indirect objects, instrumental case for means or instruments, locative case for locations, vocative case for direct address, and oblique case is sometimes used for the minor grammatical relations. These additional cases are usually marked via case markers on the nominal phrases themselves in languages which normally mark case on nouns or nominal phrases as well as pronouns. For languages without any case marking and those which only show case in the pronouns, these additional grammatical relations are normally expressed via prepositional or postpositional phrases.
In
, there are not any kind of case distinctions. Therefore, the minor grammatical relations are expressed by

case.caseText: prepositional
postpositional
prepositional or postpositional
prepositional and/or postpositional

p.content: phrases, rather than by nominal phrases.
In
, case distinctions are not marked on nouns or nominal phrases; only the pronoun sets distinguish case. Therefore, the minor grammatical relations are expressed by

case.caseText: prepositional
postpositional
prepositional or postpositional
prepositional and/or postpositional

p.content: phrases, rather than by nominal phrases. The case distinctions in the pronouns will be delineated in
In
, case is marked on both pronouns and nouns or nominal phrases.

text.content: Nominative case is the default (unmarked) case.
The case marker is written as a separate word and occurs

case.caseText: before
after
on either side of

text.content: the rest of the nominal phrase.
All of the case markers can occur on either side of the nominal phrase.
There are restrictions as to which of the case markers can occur on each side of the nominal phrase.

case.caseText: The case markers attach to the beginning of the initial word in the nominal phrase.
The case markers attach to the end of the final word in the nominal phrase.
Some of the case markers attach to the beginning of the initial word and some attach to the end of the final word in the nominal phrase.
The case markers are prefixes which attach to the head noun.
The case markers are suffixes which attach to the head noun.
Some of the case markers are prefixes and some are suffixes which attach to the head noun.

are shown in the following chart.

col.content: subjects of transitive verbs and possessors
subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs
subjects of intransitive verbs and objects of transitive verbs and possessors

p.content: The outer or top level of the nominal phrase is occupied by those degree words that modify the whole phrase, such as
, and
. These were discussed in section
To review the facts for

, the positive forms are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase. The positive special degree elements are

case.caseText: phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase.
phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
phrasal clitics which attach either to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
either prefixes or suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.

Articles and/or demonstratives normally comprise the next level moving inward towards the noun. In English, the articles are
, and
. English demonstratives include
, and
. Some simple examples are:
p.langData: a book, an apple, the book, the books, this apple
p.content: and

In English, articles and demonstratives do not co-occur in the same nominal phrase, and both occur before the noun. Some languages allow both to co-occur in the same phrase, and they may occur in different positions with respect to the noun. Therefore, they need distinct syntactic categories. Some languages only have one set, either articles or demonstratives. A few languages may not have either type expressed as separate words.

case.caseText: does not have either articles or demonstratives that are realized as separate words.
has only articles that are realized as separate words, no demonstratives.
has only demonstratives that are realized as separate words, no articles.
has both articles and demonstratives that are realized as separate words.

p.content: In

case.caseText: both the definite and indefinite articles are overt words.
only the definite article is overt; indefinite nouns are unmarked.

p.content: Further, there

case.caseText: is only one set of articles which are used with both singular and plural nouns.
are separate forms of articles for singular and plural to agree with the noun.

In many languages, possessors comprise the next level moving inward towards the noun. Possession can normally be expressed by a pronoun, by a simple noun, or by a full nominal phrase. However, Spanish only allows pronouns in the possessor position before the noun, with all noun and full nominal phrase possessors expressed in a prepositional phrase with
after the noun.
Within the languages which express possessors by nouns or full nominal phrases as well as by pronouns, many also add some kind of marking, such as the

in English, as an indication of possession. These markings are either affixes (or clitics) on the head noun or phrase-level clitics which attach to one end of the whole phrase. The English marking is this second type, because alongside phrases where the
appears to attach to the head noun, as in
, there are phrases which clearly show that the clitic attaches to the end of the whole nominal phrase, such as
p.langData: the boy that I just talked to’s mother
p.content: or
p.langData: the girl in green’s wonderful speech
p.content: . These examples show that possessors can include

case.caseText: prepositional
postpositional
prepositional and/or postpositional
prepositional and/or postpositional

p.content: phrases and relative clauses. Possessors can also be embedded in one another, as in
. This is allowed in Spanish within the prepositional phrase after the noun.
Examples of possessed nominal phrases with simple and embedded possessors in
include:
Examples with pre/post-positional phrases within the possessor include:
Examples with relative clauses within the possessor, included in simple full sentences are:
As seen in the examples above,

case.caseText: does not have any special marking to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase.
marks the head noun within the possessor with an affix to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase.
marks the whole phrase with a phrasal clitic to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase.

text.content: This phrasal clitic is an enclitic which attaches to the final word in the possessor.
This phrasal clitic is an proclitic which attaches to the first word in the possessor.
This phrasal clitic is written as a separate word which occurs

case.caseText: before
after

text.content: the possessor. The possessive clitic is

case.caseText: optional in some cases.
always required.

p.content: The possessor (especially the pronoun form, if
is like Spanish) occurs

case.caseText: before
after
on either side of

p.content: the noun being possessed.

section3.secTitle: Possessors and Articles Or Demonstratives Occuring Together

p.content: In English, possessors and articles or demonstratives do not co-occur in the same nominal phrase, unless the possessor is expressed in a prepositional phrase. For example,
is ungrammatical; instead one would use
to express the same thought. Some other languages allow both possessors and articles or demonstratives to occur in the same phrase, so the first example above would be grammatical.
In

case.caseText: some

p.content: nominal possessors

case.caseText: may
may
may not

p.content: occur in the same phrase as

case.caseText: articles
demonstratives
articles and/or demonstratives

p.content: in the normal possessor position

case.caseText: but some may not. In that case,
. Instead,

text.content: the possessor is expressed in a

case.caseText: prepositional
postpositional
prepositional or postpositional
prepositional or postpositional

text.content: phrase.

p.content: As discussed in section
does not have any case system. Therefore, there is no separate case marking on nouns nor a distinct set of pronouns used for possessors.
With the normal nominative-accusative case system followed by
, possessors are marked with the genitive case.
Possessors in
are marked with the genitive case, following the normal nominative-accusative part of the split case system. In the parts which display split ergativity, possessors are marked with the

case.caseText: ergative case, the same marking as the subjects of transitive verbs.
absolutive case, the same marking as the subjects of intransitive verbs and the objects of transitive verbs.
genitive case also.

p.content: Within the ergative-absolutive case system followed by
, possessors are marked with the

case.caseText: ergative case, the same marking as the subjects of transitive verbs.
absolutive case, the same marking as the subjects of intransitive verbs and the objects of transitive verbs.
genitive case, a distinct marking for possessors.

p.content: In some languages, in a possessed noun phrase the head noun and any modifiers matches the case of the possessor. In other languages, the possessor is marked with its own case, say genitive, while the head noun is marked with case depending on its position relative to the verb: nominative or accusative, ergative or absolutive depending on the case system.
In

case.caseText: the grammatical function of the head noun relative to the verb determines its case, not the presence of a possessor.
the case of the head noun matches the case of the possessor, when a possessor is present.

p.content: Languages like

which change the case of the head noun when a possessor is present normally also change the case of intervening adjectives to match. Some languages of this type also change the case of the head noun when only an adjectival modifier is present, even when there is no possessor.
In
, the case of the head noun

case.caseText: only changes when a possessor is present, though in that situation an intervening adjective may/must also carry that case.
changes to match the normal case of a possessor even if just an adjectival modifier is present.

p.content: Further, some languages of this latter type have an overt affix which marks the genitive case (or the normal case of possessors) on the head noun to indicate that there must be either an adjective or a possessor in that nominal phrase. In this situation, the adjective and/or possessor will also be in genitive case (or the normal case of possessors), though the case marking will not be overt on the highest modifier in the nominal phrase.
In
, the case marking

case.caseText: is not
is
is

p.content: handled in this distinctive way.

text.content: When the overt
genitive
or
ergative
absolutive

case.caseText: suffix
prefix

text.content: is present on the head noun, it indicates that an adjectival modifier and/or a possessor must be present in the phrase. If the adjective is marked with this
genitive
or
ergative
absolutive

case.caseText: suffix,
prefix,

text.content: then another adjective and/or a possessor must also be present.

p.content: Possessor agreement normally comes in two basic forms:

li.content: An affix that occurs on alienably possessed nouns to indicate that they are possessed and therefore must have a possessor in the nominal phrase. Inalienably possessed nouns do not take any marking, but must always have a possessor. These include, but are not limited to, kinship terms and body parts.
An affix that agrees with the possessor (or possibly expresses the possessor by itself).

case.caseText: does not distinguish
does make a distinction

p.content: between alienably and inalienably possessed nouns.

text.content: The affix which marks alienably possessed nouns when they have a possessor is:

p.content: In
, nouns

case.caseText: are not
are

p.content: marked with an affix which either agrees with the possessor or expresses the possessor by itself.

text.content: See the dependent personal pronouns used for possessors, given in section
. These affixes mark the following features of the possessor:

p.content: Quantifier phrases (QP) were discussed earlier in section
. Such modifiers mark the number of the whole nominal phrase. English examples of quantified nominal phrases include:
and
p.langData: only the first one hundred boys
p.content: . All the quantifier phrases occur before the noun in English.
In
, quantifier phrases occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

p.content: the noun.

text.content: All of quantifier phrases can occur on either side of the noun.
There are restrictions as to which of the quantifier phrases can occur on each side of the noun.
All of the numbers occur before the noun.
All of the numbers occur after the noun.

p.content: examples of quantified nominal phrases include:
Like other modifiers within the nominal phrase, quantifier phrases in
show agreement with the head noun in

case.caseText: animacy.
class number.
gender.

p.content: Adjective phrases (AdjP) were discussed earlier in section
. Adjective phrases occur close to the noun, yielding nominal phrases such as:
p.langData: just those very few old, dirty books
all the boy’s many black dogs
p.content: and
p.langData: only the first one hundred very eager young boys
p.content: . As the English examples show, adjectives all occur before the noun, and more than one adjective phrase is allowed. This is handled by a recursive rule.
In
, adjective phrases occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

p.content: the noun.

text.content: All of the adjective phrases can occur on either side of the noun.
There are restrictions as to which of the adjective phrases can occur on each side of the noun.

p.content: examples of nominal phrases which are modified by qualitative adjectives include:
Like other modifiers within the nominal phrase, adjective phrases in
show agreement with the head noun in

case.caseText: animacy.
class number.
gender.

p.content: Participles or participle phrases may also act as adjectives in modifying a noun. Some English examples with the participle or participle phrase bracketed include:
and
Examples in
include:

Another case which may look like a noun and a complement may actually be a gerund or gerund phrase. This whole phrase occupies a normal argument position, such as subject, object, indirect object or the object of a preposition. Some English examples in full sentences with the gerund phrase bracketed include:
p.langData: [Studying participles] is challenging, He likes [reading Latin poetry]
p.content: and
p.langData: The receiver showed his worth by [making the catch].
p.content: Such phrases may be possessed or be modified as well, and sometimes only the gerund stands alone as the head of a nominal phrase, as in
and
Therefore, we will allow gerund phrases to occupy the head of the nominal phrase.
Examples from
of gerunds or gerund phrases that can take the place of a noun in a nominal phrase include:
These gerund phrases can be used in full sentences as shown here:

Many languages are like English, in that they have noun modifiers. It may seem like all nouns can also be used as adjectives, but a closer look reveals that true adjectives come before the noun modifier, as in
but not
. Therefore, noun modifiers will be treated as compound nouns which are written as separate words.
In the English examples above,
is clearly the head noun rather than
, because
is restricting the type of
, not the other way around. In all compound nouns and noun modifier constructions in English, the head is the right-most noun in the series.
does not have any compound nouns or noun modifiers that are written as separate words. They are all written as a single word with the head noun. Examples include:
has compound nouns or noun modifiers that are written as separate words. The

case.caseText: left-most
right-most

p.content: noun is the head in these constructions. Examples include:
Both simple and compound nouns may have pre/post-positional phrase (PP) modifiers or complements, such as in
and
. In addition, genitive pre/post-positional phrases may take the place of the possessor, such as
and
. In English, the PP always comes after the noun.
In
, the PP occurs

case.caseText: before
after
on either side of

p.content: the head noun.
examples with PP modifiers or complements include:
